text.text: What should I do if a patient only has one more scheduled invoice?

text: If a patient only has one more scheduled invoice, you can use the "Final statement pending" tab to send final notices, call the patient to ask for a payment, or inquire if they received retroactive Medicaid. You can also download the data to a CSV file for review.

text.text: launch me to patient billing page

text: Link: PatientBilling/Index

text.text: How do I navigate to the Patient Billing page?

text: To get to the Patient Billing page, hover over Claims on the navigation bar and click Patient Billing.

text.text: What information can I find on the "Active" tab of the Patient Billing page?

text: The "Active" tab shows all accounts that have at least one claim in the account where the patient is the current payer. On this tab you can find the: patient name, account number, the date the last statement was sent, amount paid by the patient, and outstanding patient responsibility.

text.text: What should I do if a patient only has one more scheduled invoice?

text: You can use the "Final statement pending" tab to send final notices, call the patient to ask for a payment, or inquire if they received retroactive Medicaid.

text.text: What actions can I take for accounts listed under the "Final statement sent" tab?

text: You can send another patient statement, move this account to collection agency/state debt collections, or write off the amount as bad debt. You can also click "Send another statement" to remove the suspension and change the status on the claims associated with the account to "Queued for submission â€“ Patient statement".

text.text: How do I see which accounts have had a collections letter sent?

text: The "Collections letter sent" tab shows the account, number of claims, last statement date, the day you sent the collection letter, and account balance. When this is the case, the account displays under the "Final statement sent" tab on the Patient Billing page.

text.text: How can I manually suspend a patient's billing account?

text: You can manually suspend an account by clicking the "Review" icon and then the "Suspend patient billing" button. The reason for the suspension displays under the "Suspension reason" column. Accounts under this tab need to be worked daily.

text.text: What happens when I suspend an account with an estate reason?

text: If the account is suspended with one of these estate reasons, invoices will not be generated for this patient. Estate suspended accounts can be managed on the Patient Billing page under the "Estates" tab.

text.text: Where do I find accounts that have negotiated payment plans?

text: The "Payment plans" tab shows a list of patients that have a negotiated payment. Click the icon under the "Review" column to remove the patient from the plan, determine future steps, and view open claims and patient statements.

text.text: How do I filter the information displayed on any tab in the Patient Billing page?

text: You can filter the information displayed on any tab in the Patient Billing page by using the boxes under the column headings. You can also sort rows by clicking the heading name.

text.text: How can I change the number of days between patient statements and the total number of statements?

text: To change the schedule, use the following steps: 1. In the navigation bar, click Settings. 2. On the Configuration tab, scroll down to the "Patient billing" section. 3. Click on the days field and select a value from the list. 4. Click the statement field and select a value from the list. 5. On the bottom of the page, click Save.

text.text: What information can I find when I review a patient's account?

text: When you review a patient's account, you can find the following information:

text.text: What should I do if I want to move an account to a collection agency?

text: To move an account to a collection agency, you can use the "Move to Collections Agency" button on the "Patient responsibility" tab. The first time you click this button, you will need to enter the collection agency information. The status of all the claims in patient billing for that account changes to "Closed - In collections". The write off amount displays on the "Move to collection agency" window. In addition, we add the collections agency as the final payer on the claim level COB. This allows you to post payments from the collections agency when they collect money.

text.text: How do I suspend a patient's billing account manually?

text: To manually suspend an account, you can click the "Review" icon and then the "Suspend patient billing" button. The reason for the suspension displays under the "Suspension reason" column. Accounts under this tab need to be worked daily.

text.text: What happens to invoices when an account is automatically suspended due to exceeding the number of sent invoices?

text: To remove the suspension, click "Send another statement". This action removes the account from the list on the "Final statement sent" tab and changes the status on the claims associated with the account to "Queued for submission â€“ Patient statement".

text.text: How can I write off an account balance as bad debt?

text: To write off an account balance as bad debt, you can use the "Write off as bad debt" option. After you click Confirm, the status for all the claims associated with the account changes to "Closed â€“ Balance resolved". The system shows the write off amount.

text.text: Where do I find the running balance of all claims associated with an account?

text: The running account balance tab shows the running balance of all the claims associated with the account. This list is dynamic, as claims are added or payments are made, the running balance changes. There is an option to print the running balance.

text.text: How do I view claim details for claims sent to collections or state debt?

text: The claims in collections tab shows a list of claim numbers associated with this account that have been sent to collections or state debt. Click the claim number to view the claim details.

text.text: What action should I take if the patient's credit score is over 600 and they have a high likelihood to pay?

text: You may want to send another statement.

text.text: What can I do if the patientâ€™s income compared to the Federal Poverty Level (FPL) is low?

text: You may want to contact the patient and see if enrollment in Medicaid is an option. If the credit score and likelihood to pay are low, and the patient has never made a payment, you may want to either move the account to collections or write off the balance as bad debt.

text.text: How do I generate an additional statement for accounts on the "Final statement sent" or "Other suspensions" tab?

text: If you are in the "Final statement sent" or "Other suspensions" tab and the number of sent statements exceeds the maximum number configured in the statement schedule, you can generate an additional statement by clicking the "Send another statement" button.

text.text: What should I consider if the patient's credit score and likelihood to pay are low, and they have never made a payment?

text: You may want to either move the account to collections or write off the balance as bad debt.

text.text: How can I add a collection agency to an account for the first time?

text: The only place you can add a collection agency is on the Patient responsibility tab. The first time you click the Move to Collections Agency button, you will need to enter the collection agency information. Once entered, you will have the option to select that collection agency or create a new one.

text.text: Where can I see the details of the last statement sent to a patient?

text: The "Active" tab shows all accounts that have at least one claim in the account where the patient is the current payer. On this tab you can find the patient name, account number, the date the last statement was sent, amount paid by the patient, and outstanding patient responsibility.

text.text: How do I remove a patient from a payment plan?

text: To remove a patient from a payment plan, click the icon under the "Review" column on the Payment plans tab. This will allow you to remove the patient from the plan, determine future steps, and view open claims and patient statements.

text.text: What should I do if I need to review a patient's propensity-to-pay information?

text: To review a patient's propensity-to-pay information, you can click the review icon to view the patient's account. This page will help you to determine the best way to deal with the account. It shows the patientâ€™s propensity-to-pay, current patient responsibility, running balance, and statement details.
